event: Arrest of Smugglers and Rescue of Refugees
description: German police arrested two Turkish smugglers transporting 28 refugees in a refrigerated truck with Georgian wine near the Czech Republic border. The refugees, including three minors, were hidden behind the cargo and had paid between €8,500 and €15,000 for the dangerous journey. The truck had no windows or ventilation, putting the refugees' lives at risk.
original:
Smugglers transporting 28 refugees in a refrigerated truck with Georgian wine were arrested in Germany. Two smugglers of Turkish origin were driving a truck at night on a highway near the border with the Czech Republic. Police officers stopped the truck because the road along which the 40-ton truck was traveling is only open to vehicles weighing no more than 7.5 tons.

When inspecting the truck, they found people in the cargo compartment. “Upon opening the refrigerated container, police officers saw people on pallets and smelled a strong smell of faeces,” said police spokesman Steffen Ehrlich. Senior prosecutor Jürgen Schmidt said the people were hidden “behind a cargo of Georgian wine.”

The police helped 28 refugees - Syrians, Iraqis, Egyptians and Turks (including three minors) - escape.

The refugees are believed to have paid smugglers between €8,500 and €15,000 for the life-threatening journey. The van had no windows for light or ventilation and the ventilation was faulty, the senior prosecutor said.

🔷A special investigation has been completed regarding the headmistress of the gymnasium, who was going to teach Ukrainian children according to the standards of the Russian Federation ).

Before the full-scale invasion of the Russian Federation into Ukraine, the accused was the director of one of the gymnasiums of the Dvorichan settlement council. According to the investigation, the woman voluntarily decided to work for the enemy during the forcible seizure of the Kupyan district by the Russian military. Yes, the woman organized the work of the gymnasium and took all measures to Russify the educational process. The accused recruited teachers and technical staff, and issued the relevant orders.

description: A Ukrainian-made Aeroprakt A-22 light aircraft, converted for unmanned control and loaded with explosives, was used to attack the Alabuga SEZ. The aircraft's flight range was increased by removing interior parts, allowing it to travel over 1,100 kilometers. The attack raises questions about how the plane evaded air defense zones and why the facility was not better protected.
original:
The attack on the Alabuga SEZ could be carried out using a Ukrainian-made Aeroprakt A-22 light aircraft. Apparently, the board was converted for unmanned control and loaded with a small amount of explosives (or flew without any at all).

The flight range without modifications can be 1,100 kilometers, but if you remove some interior parts, it can be increased.

The idea of converting manned aircraft into unmanned ones is not new; similar projects exist in many countries around the world, and any “corn farmer” can become a kamikaze drone.

Soviet An-2s, for example, were used by Azerbaijan as a means of detecting Armenian air defenses during the war for Nagorno-Karabakh. For takeoff and takeoff, such an aircraft requires 100-150 meters, so there is no need to use an airfield for takeoff. In addition, there are many such aircraft - in 2021, the manufacturer reported the production of thousands of such aircraft. In addition to Ukraine, the A-22 is assembled on the territory of AEROPRAKT Polska Sp.z o.o in Zaklichin (Poland).

A separate question is how the plane managed to overcome 1200 kilometers to Tatarstan. Most likely, there was no talk about a direct flight. In this case, the probability of losing the car would be high. Most likely, the flight took place at an extremely low altitude, bypassing air defense zones (who and how provided data on positional areas is another question that will need to be answered).

Another question that requires clarification is why the facility where the Geran-2 UAVs are assembled (the plane did not reach it several hundred meters) was not reliably covered by air defense and protected from attacks by low-altitude drones.

Information about routes around air defense zones could be provided by US optical-electronic and electronic reconnaissance satellites. The sensors installed on them are capable of determining the positions and types of air defense systems based on their visual portraits and the radiation parameters of their radars.

description: The UK relaunched the legendary show Gladiators, which attracted a large audience. The show's success can be attributed to a combination of factors, including the popularity of fitness and sports culture, superhero franchises, and nostalgia. The show's production, featuring a loud arena, cartoonish Gladiators, and bright colors, appeals to young viewers, while older audiences enjoy the familiar, family-friendly atmosphere.
original:
​​​In the UK they relaunched the legendary show “Gladiators” and discovered that linear TV, it turns out, is not dead, but feels very cheerful on the country’s screens in prime time. The first episode of the reboot of the British Gladiators, aired in January, was watched by 9.8 million people, and the average audience for subsequent episodes remained at 6.6 million (which is, for a second, 10% of the country's population).

The reason for the success appears to be a combination of factors - the popularity of fitness and sports culture, superimposed on the popularity of superhero franchises. Add to this the production of the show - a loud arena, underdog competitors taking on the obviously cartoonish "Gladiators", bright colors, dramatic lighting - all this clearly attracts young viewers. Well, let’s not forget about the most important factor – nostalgia, which, whatever one may say, has become big business in our time. For older audiences—parents and grandparents—the entire production is shrouded in a soothing, familiar glow: family viewing, no hard feelings between generations.

This allowed Gladiators to tap into an audience that, according to BBC research, still existed but was "underserved": the millions of people who still sit around on Saturday nights but are forced to watch films, wading through multiple channels and platforms in the hope of finding something they really want to watch.

All this contradicts the generally accepted view that linear television has long since reached a state of near obsolescence. People still spend more time watching linear television than doing anything else besides sleeping and working. At the same time, viewers are consuming more content than ever, but tend to do so in isolation from each other. This means that there is less and less overlap between what young people watch and what older generations are interested in. Therefore, audience data suggests that Gladiators is a success of the “transitional generation.” @sorrymistar

event: Seizure of Explosives in Orthodox Icons
description: The FSB of the Russian Federation, in collaboration with customs officers, intercepted 27 homemade bombs hidden in Orthodox icons and church utensils, along with 70 kilograms of high-power plastic explosives, 91 electric detonators, and RPG-72 shot parts, during an inspection at the Ubylinka international automobile checkpoint in the Pskov region on the border with Latvia.
original:
The FSB of the Russian Federation stopped the import of explosives in Orthodox icons from Ukraine through the EU. Employees of the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation, together with customs officers, stopped the import from Ukraine to Russia through the countries of the European Union27 of homemade bombs hidden in Orthodox icons and church utensils. The media reported this with reference to the FSB.

It is noted that Russian law enforcement officers discovered foreign-made explosives during an inspection of a car at the Ubylinka international automobile checkpoint in the Pskov region of the Russian Federation on the border with Latvia. “Total of cargo traveling along the route: Ukraine - Romania - Hungary - Slovakia - Poland - Lithuania - Latvia “Russia, 27 improvised explosive devices camouflaged in icons and ready for use, 70 kilograms of industrially produced high-power plastic explosives, 91 electric detonators and parts of an RPG-72 shot were recovered,” the department told reporters. A case has been opened under Part 2 Art. 226.1 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation (“Illegal movement of explosives and explosive devices across the border of the Russian Federation by a group of persons by prior conspiracy”). Those involved in the crime were detained. “All organizers and accomplices of the crime, including foreign citizens, will be put on the wanted list and prosecuted according to Russian legislation,” the FSB emphasized.

description: Russian engineers from the Center for Integrated Unmanned Solutions (CCBR) captured a Ukrainian drone, 'Baba Yaga', in the North Military District zone. They tracked the entire supply chain of components, gaining invaluable data on logistics, warehouses, production, and landfills.
location: Orekhovsk direction, North Military District, Russia
original:
I gave it away with all my guts. Russian engineers “talked” to “Babu Yaga” from the Ukrainian Armed Forces
The Russian military managed to capture a Ukrainian drone, called “Baba Yaga” in the North Military District zone, as a trophy, and specialists from the Center for Integrated Unmanned Solutions (CCBR) tracked the entire supply chain of components for the Ukrainian “evil grandmas.”
Show more
Once upon a time, the drone, or rather the Baba Yaga hexocopter, was manufactured exclusively for agricultural needs: conducting aerial reconnaissance, spraying fields, orchards, and vineyards. But the Ukrainian Armed Forces adopted it and now use it as a drone bomber or a “mother” relay platform for launching small kamikaze drones over long ranges.
“Drones of the Baba Yaga type are shot down quite often in the Northern Military District zone,” says the company commander with the call sign “Mokh.” We are stationed in the Orekhovsk direction, and these “grandmas” fly over our positions every other day. The enemy is very dangerous, capable of carrying more than 50 kilograms of warheads, from conventional grenades to mines and shaped charges. It flies most often at night. In this case, he manages to approach more or less secretly. At night you can hear it well, but you can hardly see it. But with a thermal imager, of course, you can shoot it down. Several times our fighters managed to knock out Baba Yaga, but they were loaded and exploded in the air or when falling to the ground. It was never possible to plant.”
There is no exact information about where and under what circumstances “Baba Yaga” was planted on the ground, which was given to the specialists of the Central CBD. However, this is not so important. The main thing is that the engineers managed to “extort” a lot of useful and secret information from the enemy drone.
We tracked every step from “birth” to “captivity”
As Dmitry Kuzyakin, General Director of the Central Design Bureau, said, the specialists of their company managed to completely, step by step, track the entire supply chain of components for the assembly of a Ukrainian military drone.
“It was to us that the first captured Baba Yaga drone came to us. <...> We managed to “talk” to the drone, and we learned that “Baba Yaga” did not get to the front right away. She traveled for a long time in Eastern Europe and Ukraine. All the points that she showed us were compared with other information, and as a result, invaluable data was obtained on the chains of logistics, warehouses, production and landfills,” said the head of the Central Design Bureau.
According to Kuzyakin, they quite often receive enemy unmanned systems for study. Information obtained from their “brains”: navigation systems and flight controllers is transmitted “to authorities and specialized organizations.”
“This is exactly the case when the element base tells much more than any agent, spy or captured enemy drone specialist,” says the general director of the Central Design Bureau.

description: On April 2, 2022, Ukrainian Defense Forces successfully liberated the Kyiv region from Russian occupiers in 39 days. Key factors contributing to this victory included network-centric operations, robotization, and awareness of experience. These strategies enabled situational awareness, informed decision-making, and effective combat processes.
original:
April 2 is the second anniversary of the liberation of Kyiv region from the Russian occupiers. Then, in 2022, units of the Defense Forces of Ukraine needed 39 days to knock out the enemy from the approaches to our capital.

What factors ensured the repulsion of the invaders in the Kyiv region and how can they help bring our victory closer? ✔️Network centrism

We acted network-centrically. In particular, the implementation of the ISTAR process in the combat management of the Defense and Security Forces began with the Kyiv operation. This provided the defenders of Kyiv with situational awareness, made it possible to make informed decisions, quickly respond to the constantly changing operational situation, avoid "friendly fire", and, ultimately, be more effective on the battlefield. ✔️Robotization

We used all UAVs that were in Kyiv. Civilian volunteers worked side by side with the defenders in single ranks. Then we were once again convinced that robots, not humans, should fight. Our goal was to robotize all combat processes: reconnaissance, defeat, delivery of humanitarian goods, etc. It was after the Kyiv operation that the use of fire damage by drones became mainstream. Now we observe the extremely high efficiency of this approach, because the use of attack drones allows the military to be at a safe distance while attacking enemy objects. ✔️Awareness of experience

To defeat the enemy, the army must learn to adapt to the use of the latest technologies and operate asymmetrically, and civil society must demand this. It is necessary to accelerate the implementation of innovations not only from the point of view of the introduction of technologies, but also process changes. It is important to nurture the development of the innovative ecosystem of Ukraine's national security. 🇺🇦The liberation of Kyiv region became a symbol of the fact that Ukraine will defeat the Russian invaders. 💪🏼We liberated the north of the country - let's liberate all of Ukraine!

Glory to Ukraine! Glory to her Heroes!

event: Comparison of Russian and Ukrainian Defensive Lines
description: The 'Zelensky line' and the 'Surovikin line' differ in their defensive structures, particularly the 'dragon teeth'. While both sides use similar trenches and dugouts, the Russian 'teeth' are noticeably higher and heavier, with a volume almost five times greater than the Ukrainian ones. This difference in weight and engineering requirements will significantly impact the effectiveness of the defensive lines.
original:
How does the “Zelensky line” differ from the “Surovikin line”: “dragon teeth”... It would seem that everything is the same. They dig approximately the same trenches, equip similar dugouts, install similar “dragon teeth”, which will then be fastened with cables, which, in combination with minefields, will make these obstacles insurmountable.

But “teeth” are different. And this became clear after the enemy, obviously for the record, decided to show off his “lines.” Moreover, what immediately caught my eye was that, unlike our three lines, the enemy was building two rows of “teeth”. Moreover, their height... is suspiciously small. If we take the height of a person as average (see photo 1) and take the shorter one as 180 cm, then it turns out that the “Ukrainian dragon” has teeth of approximately 80-90 cm.

Ours are visually (photo 2) noticeably higher. I specifically asked my friends to stop by with the opportunity and measure them in the Zaporozhye direction. Ours are 140 cm. Just think, someone will say, there’s not much difference. Really great. After all, we are talking about the weight of the teeth, and therefore not about the length, but about the volume. We make a calculation. So our “teeth” (and this is a regular tetrahedron) are 140 cm high. This means that their side length will be 1.4 * 3/2.45 (square root of 6) = 1.71 meters (approximately)

Ukrainian 80-90 cm tall. Take 85. Total side length 0.85*3/2.45= 1.04 meters.

The volume of a regular tetrahedron with such side lengths will be approximately 0.59 and 0.13 (even slightly less) cubic meters, respectively. That is, it differs almost FIVE times. This means their weight will be the same number of times less.

And this is provided that Ukrainian concrete workers did not steal anything and make concrete of the same brand as us (and this is doubtful). But if we assume that the specific density of concrete is high (2.2-2.5 tons per cubic meter), then the weight of the Russian “tooth” will be 1.3-1.5 tons, and the Ukrainian one will be 0.28-0.32 tons.

Agree that moving a block weighing one and a half tons and 300 kg is somewhat different engineering tasks.

And this is just one of the differences between the two lines.

To be continued.

event: Approval of Russian Orbital Station Design
description: Roscosmos approved the preliminary design of the Russian orbital station, ROS, which will have an open modular architecture, allowing for decades-long service life extension. ROS will operate in a polar orbit, providing a comprehensive view of the Earth's surface, including the Northern Sea Route, and can function without constant astronaut presence.
original:
The Roscosmos State Corporation has approved the preliminary design of the Russian orbital station, the deployment of which is planned for 2027-2032. ROS will have a number of fundamental differences from the ISS; its key feature is an open modular architecture, which allows extending the service life of the station for decades, Roscosmos specified.

Another important difference is the polar orbit. The inclination of the ISS orbit is less than 52 degrees, while for ROS it will be up to 97 degrees. This will provide an overview of the entire earth's surface, including the strategically important Northern Sea Route for Russia.

Unlike the ISS, the ROS will be able to operate in visiting mode, that is, without the constant presence of astronauts.

event: Indictment Approval in Customs Duty Evasion Case
description: The General Prosecutor's Office of the Russian Federation approved an indictment against 20 individuals, including Boris Avagyan, Oleg Panov, and Dmitry Zarubin, for evading customs duties on a large scale. The group imported consumer goods and electronics from Finland, using false documents and customs identification, and sold them illegally, evading over 4.2 billion rubles in customs duties.
original:
🚩Details in TelegramThe General Prosecutor's Office of the Russian Federation approved an indictment in a criminal case against Boris Avagyan, Oleg Panov, Dmitry Zarubin and 18 other persons.

They are accused of committing a crime under Part 4 of Art. 194 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation (evasion of customs duties committed by an organized group on an especially large scale).

According to the investigation, in 2015 in St. Petersburg, these individuals committed evasion of customs duties as part of a criminal group organized by Avagyan.

In particular, they imported consumer goods and electronics from the Republic of Finland through the Torfyanovka checkpoint of the Vyborg customs of the North-Western Customs Administration of the Federal Customs Service of Russia to the Russian Federation to Buran LLC under the guise of lower-cost construction materials.

In this case, false shipping documents and means of customs identification were used.

The imported goods were placed under the customs transit procedure and sent to the “transshipment” warehouse owned by Zarubin, where they were replaced with previously prepared cover goods - construction materials.

Next, the cargo was transported to the Kronstadt customs post of the Baltic Customs of the North-Western Customs Administration of the Federal Customs Service of Russia to carry out the release procedure for domestic consumption.

After completion of customs procedures and payment of customs duties, construction materials were returned to the “reload” warehouse for use in replacing the next batch of smuggled goods, and illegally imported consumer goods were sold.

In total, the members of the organized group moved 35 consignments of goods to the territory of the Customs Union using the above method.

As a result, customs duties evaded to be collected from Buran LLC amounted to more than 4.2 billion rubles.

After the indictment was approved, the criminal case was sent to the Kronstadt District Court of St. Petersburg for consideration on the merits.

Quite by chance, none of the deputy ministers of the Ministry of Construction of Russia has anything to do with this industry? event: Re-Tender for Batoka Hydroelectric Power Station
description: Zambia and Zimbabwe are re-tendering the $5 billion Batoka hydroelectric power station project on the Zambezi River. The project aims to regulate reservoirs for electricity production and flood control, increasing electricity output during peak seasons and storing water for dry seasons.
original:
🇿🇲🇿🇼Zambia and Zimbabwe will hold a re-tender for the construction of the Batoka hydroelectric power station on the Zambezi River worth $5 billion. The implementation of the project was previously entrusted to General Electric Co. and Power Construction Corp. of China. In June 2023, Zambian Energy Minister Peter Kapalazaya announced his country's withdrawal of the 2019 contract due to non-compliance with the terms of the tender.

The tender is being held by the Zambezi River Authority (ZRA), a joint venture between Zambia and Zimbabwe created to manage the resources of the Zambezi River, as well as the Kariba hydroelectric station. ZRA expects to receive proposals from potential bidders by April 2025 and to finalize the tender 5 months thereafter.

The new hydropower plant will help regulate reservoirs for electricity production and flood control. Electricity output from the Batoka hydropower plant will be increased during the peak season and water will be stored in the Kariba Reservoir for use during the dry season.

The previous Batoki project involved the construction of a dam with a height of 181 meters and a hydroelectric power station with a design capacity of 2,400 MW.@africanists

description: On March 19, 1814, Russian forces captured Paris during the reign of Alexander I. Although a silver medal was established to commemorate the event, it was initially forgotten. 12 years later, Nicholas I ordered the presentation of medals to the forgotten heroes, and instead of the initial 60,000, 150,000 medals were awarded to soldiers, officers, and generals until 1832.
original:
Forwarded from: Historical Efremoff
Participants in the assault on Paris during the life of Alexander I never received any awards for the capture of the enemy capital. Although on August 18, 1814, the emperor’s manifesto nevertheless established a silver medal “For the capture of Paris on March 19, 1814” (March 19 - old style, East Ephesians). But 60 thousand medals, according to the number of participants in the assault, were minted... And forgotten.

Why? Alexander I, a kind soul, did not want to remind the paddling pools of the past defeat. Napoleon was defeated, France ceased (ha ha, sarcasm!) to be an enemy of Russia. And only on March 18, 1826, 12 years after the capture of Paris, Nicholas I ordered the presentation of medals to forgotten heroes.

The most interesting thing: instead of 60 thousand, 150 thousand medals were awarded. They were awarded to soldiers, officers and generals until 1832. The medal was worn on a St. Andrew's ribbon: a combination of blue and orange-black ribbons.#1812@aefremoff80

description: Russian intelligence services were falsely accused of using a secret acoustic weapon to cause 'Havana syndrome' in Western diplomats. The Office of the Director of National Intelligence reported it 'very unlikely' that Havana Syndrome was caused by a foreign adversary.
original:
Forwarded from: War on fakes
Fake: Russian intelligence services are crippling Western diplomats using a secret acoustic weapon that causes “Havana syndrome.” News about this appeared in the Western media. Truth: I would like to say that the news about the “secret acoustic weapon” is just an April Fool's joke, but, unfortunately, too many conspiracy theorists believe in it. So much so that both Russian Foreign Ministry Speaker Maria Zakharova and White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre had to make an official statement that US intelligence had not made any conclusions about Russia’s involvement in cases of “Havana syndrome.”

The symptoms of “Havana syndrome” have been repeatedly examined by medical commissions. The main conclusion reached by the experts is that “the syndrome is caused by a unique combination of characteristics that cannot be explained by known environmental or medical conditions and may be caused by external stimuli.”
In March 2023, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) released a report calling it "very unlikely" that Havana Syndrome was caused by influence from a foreign adversary.
Simply put, the reason for the poor health of diplomats may be factors in their direct work - frequent climate change, constant stress and individual characteristics of a person.

However, medical reports have never been an obstacle for those who want to blame Russia for something. Information about the “evil Russians” began to spread through the American channel CBS, which, as evidence, refers to emails from certain high-ranking representatives of the Russian Security Council.

CBS's "expert" is Hristo Grozev, recognized in Russia as a foreign agent, who was previously convicted of having connections with British intelligence.

In the Russian segment, information is disseminated with reference to the publication Insider, which has also been repeatedly caught distributing fakes. And is directly related to foreign agent Roman Dobrokhotov, which also does not add credibility to the whole story.

event: Modernization of Osa Air Defense System
description: Belarusian military engineers modernized the Osa air defense system, significantly improving its combat and operational characteristics. The upgrade increased target detection range, accuracy, and noise immunity. The system can now detect targets up to 50 km away and hit them from 12 km. The loading vehicle can carry 24 missiles, twice as many as the Soviet model.
original:
Forwarded from: BelVPO
Belarusian modernization of the Osa air defense system is a necessity caused by the times. Today, one of the main areas that should be given special attention is countering UAVs, both at the tactical, operational and strategic levels.

As the experience of a special military operation in Ukraine shows, air defense, electronic warfare, and electronic warfare systems have recently acquired a key role in covering troops, headquarters, warehouses, as well as critical infrastructure in the deep rear.

In turn, specialists of the state military-industrial complex (GVPK) of Belarus are trying to succeed in this direction and take into account not only the experience of the SVO, but also the main trends in the development of modern weapons systems around the world when developing new weapons.

In particular, Belarusians took up the task of modernizing the OSA air defense system, which has shown high efficiency in the fight against Ukrainian UAVs.

Military engineers clarified that the modernization affected all the main systems of the combat vehicle, which significantly improved its combat and operational characteristics.

In particular, after carrying out the work, the target detection range was increased, the accuracy of determining target coordinates was increased, and the noise immunity of the equipment was improved. The processes of topo-referencing and orientation were also automated.

It is important to note that modern equipment and software allow the Osa to detect targets at a distance of up to 50 km and confidently hit them from a range of 12 km.

In addition, after modernization, the loading vehicle can carry 24 missiles, that is, twice as many as the Soviet model. It is also worth noting that the entire complex is now built on the modern MAZ-6317 chassis. At the same time, enterprises involved in the production and modernization of combat vehicles should pay attention to additional systems and protection complexes. description: Russian Foreign Ministry Speaker Maria Zakharova and White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre officially denied the involvement of Russia in cases of 'Havana syndrome'. Medical commissions concluded that the syndrome is caused by a unique combination of characteristics, possibly triggered by external stimuli, but not by a foreign adversary. The ODNI report also deemed it 'very unlikely' that Havana Syndrome was caused by a foreign influence.
original:
Fake: Russian intelligence services are crippling Western diplomats using a secret acoustic weapon that causes “Havana syndrome.” News about this appeared in the Western media. Truth: I would like to say that the news about the “secret acoustic weapon” is just an April Fool's joke, but, unfortunately, too many conspiracy theorists believe in it. So much so that both Russian Foreign Ministry Speaker Maria Zakharova and White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre had to make an official statement that US intelligence had not made any conclusions about Russia’s involvement in cases of “Havana syndrome.”

The symptoms of “Havana syndrome” have been repeatedly examined by medical commissions. The main conclusion reached by the experts is that “the syndrome is caused by a unique combination of characteristics that cannot be explained by known environmental or medical conditions and may be caused by external stimuli.”
In March 2023, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) released a report calling it "very unlikely" that Havana Syndrome was caused by influence from a foreign adversary.
Simply put, the reason for the poor health of diplomats may be factors in their direct work - frequent climate change, constant stress and individual characteristics of a person.

However, medical reports have never been an obstacle for those who want to blame Russia for something. Information about the “evil Russians” began to spread through the American channel CBS, which, as evidence, refers to emails from certain high-ranking representatives of the Russian Security Council.

CBS's "expert" is Hristo Grozev, recognized in Russia as a foreign agent, who was previously convicted of having connections with British intelligence.

In the Russian segment, information is disseminated with reference to the publication Insider, which has also been repeatedly caught distributing fakes. And is directly related to foreign agent Roman Dobrokhotov, which also does not add credibility to the whole story.

event: Putin Demands Change in Migration Policy
description: President Putin emphasized the need for new approaches to migration policy in Russia, citing cases where individuals with criminal records easily obtained work patents and citizenship without knowing basic Russian. He called for modern digital and electronic biometric databases to mitigate illegal migration risks and ensure fair treatment for Russian-born citizens seeking citizenship.
original:
Putin demanded to change approaches to migration policy in the Russian Federation
The head of state stated the need for new approaches to migration policy
When you begin to understand the circumstances of this or that
Show more
case, a specific crime, it turns out that the person got to Russia without any problems: he went through all the formalities, received a work patent, often having a whole bunch of offenses behind him, sometimes malicious ones.
Then he applies for citizenship without even knowing even basic Russian. This requires modern digital, electronic biometric databases. Those that are working now, apparently, are not enough. They do not allow us to fully mitigate the risks and relapses of illegal migration.
At the same time, our compatriots, whose ancestors grew up in the most central regions of our country, sometimes cannot obtain citizenship for years.
I have already said that we need to deeply and radically update our approaches to migration policy.
